titleStmt.title: Torus Chiral n-Point Functions for Free Boson and Lattice Vertex Operator Algebras

analytic.title: Torus Chiral n-Point Functions for Free Boson and Lattice Vertex Operator Algebras

abstract.p: We obtain explicit expressions for all genus one chiral n-point functions for free bosonic and lattice vertex operator algebras. We also consider the elliptic properties of these functions.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: This is the first of several papers devoted to a detailed and mathematically rigorous study of chiral n-point functions at all genera. Given a vertex operator algebra (VOA) V (i.e. a chiral conformal field theory) one may define n-point functions at genus one following Zhu [Z] and use various sewing procedures to define such functions at successively higher genera. In order to implement such a procedure in practice, one needs a detailed description of the genus one functions. This itself is a non-trivial issue, and little seems to be currently rigorously known beyond certain global descriptions for some specific theories [DMN], [DM]. The purpose of the present paper is to supply the needed information in case V is either a free bosonic or lattice VOA. More precisely, if V is a free bosonic Heisenberg or lattice VOA, N a V -module, and v 1 , . . . , v n states in V , we establish a closed formula below in Theorem 3.14 for the genus one n-point function F N (v 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n , z n ; τ ). Roughly speaking, in the free boson case the n-point functions are elliptic functions whose detailed structure depends on certain combinatorial data determined by the states v 1 , . . . , v n . In the lattice case, the function is naturally the product of two pieces, one determined by the Heisenberg subalgebra and one which may be described in terms of the lattice and the genus one prime form. We note that the role played by elliptic functions and the prime form in calculating genus one n-point functions in string theory has long been discussed by physicists but a rigorous and complete description of these n-point functions has been lacking until now e.g. [D, P].

The paper is organized as follows. We begin in section 2 with a brief review of relevant aspects of free bosonic Heisenberg and even lattice vertex operator algebras. Section 3 contains the main results of this work. We begin with a discussion of free bosonic and lattice VOAs of rank one and later generalise to the rank l case. We firstly use a recursion formula for n-point functions due to Zhu [Z] to demonstrate that every lattice n-point function is a product of a part determined by the free bosonic Heisenberg sub-VOA and a part dependent on lattice vectors only. We also obtain an explicit expression for every free bosonic n-point function F N (v 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n , z n ; τ ) in terms of a combinatoric sum over specific elliptic functions labelled by data determined by the states v 1 , . . . , v n . We next describe the n-point functions for pure lattice states. This involves the identification of such n-point functions as a sum of appropriate weights over a certain set of graphs. This combinatorial approach then leads to a closed expression for all such n-point functions in terms of the lattice vectors and the genus one prime form. Finally we conclude the section with Theorem 3.14 which describes the expression for every rank l lattice n-point function. Section 4 concludes the paper with a discussion of these n-point function from the point of view of their symmetry and elliptic properties. This provides some further insight into the nature of the explicit formulas obtained for n-point functions in Section 3. We collect here notation for some of the more frequently occurring functions and symbols that will play a role in our work. N = {1, 2, 3, ....} is the set of positive integers, Z the integers, C the complex numbers, H the complex upper-half plane. We will always take τ to lie in H, and z will lie in C unless otherwise noted. We set q z = exp(z) and q = q 2πiτ = exp(2πiτ ). For n symbols z 1 , . . . , z n we also set q i = exp(z i ) and z ij = z i − z j .
We now define some elliptic and modular functions. Let ℘(z, ω 1 , ω 2 ) denote the Weierstrass elliptic ℘-function with periods ω 1 , ω 2 and set

figure.trash: ℘(z, 2πi, 2πiτ ) = 1 z 2 + ∞ k=4,k even (k − 1)E k (τ )z k−2 , (1) so that E k (τ ) = − B k k! + 2 (k − 1)! ∞ n=1 σ k−1 (n)q n , k ∈ N, k even (2)

div.p: is the Eisenstein series of weight k normalized as in [DLM]; B k is a certain Bernoulli number and σ k−1 (n) a power sum over positive divisors of n.

figure.trash: Also set E k (τ ) = 0, k ∈ N, k odd. (3) We define P 0 (z, τ ) = − log z + ∞ k=2 1 k E k (τ )z k , (4)

div.p: related to the genus one prime form K(z, τ ) [Mu]

figure.figDesc: by
figure.trash: K(z, τ ) = exp(−P 0 (z, τ )). (5) We further define P n (z, τ ) = (−1) n (n − 1)! d n dz n P 0 (z, τ ) = 1 z n + ∞ k=2 k − 1 n − 1 E k (τ )z k−n (6) Note that P 1 (z, τ ) = ς(z, 2πi, 2πiτ ) − E 2 (τ )z, for ς the Weierstrass zetafunction and P 2 (z, τ ) = ℘(z, 2πi, 2πiτ ) + E 2 (τ ). We note two expansions for P 2 : P 2 (z − w, τ ) = 1 (z − w) 2 + r,s∈N C(r, s, τ )z r−1 w s−1 , (7) P 2 (z + w 1 − w 2 ) = r,s∈N D(r, s, z, τ )w r−1 1 w s−1 2 . (8) (expanding the latter in w 1 , w 2 ) so that for r, s ∈ N, C(r, s) = C(r, s, τ ) = (−1) r+1 (r + s − 1)! (r − 1)!(s − 1)! E r+s (τ ), (9) D(r, s, z) = D(r, s, z, τ ) = (−1) r+1 (r + s − 1)! (r − 1)!(s − 1)! P r+s (z, τ ). (10) We also define for r ∈ N, C(r, 0) = C(r, 0, τ ) = (−1) r+1 E r (τ ), (11) D(r, 0, z) = D(r, 0, z, τ ) = (−1) r+1 P r (z, τ ). (12) The Dedekind eta-function is defined by η(τ ) = q 1/24 ∞ n=1 (1 − q n ). (13) Finally, for a (finite) set Φ we denote by Σ(Φ) the symmetric group consisting of all permutations of Φ. Set Inv(Φ) = {σ ∈ Σ(Φ)|σ 2 = 1}, (involutions of Σ(Φ)), (14)

div.p: Fix(σ) = {x ∈ Φ|σ(x) = x}, (fixed-points of σ), (15) F (Φ) = {σ ∈ Inv(Φ)|Fix(σ) = ∅}, (fixed-point-free involutions of Σ(Φ)). (16)

div.head: Vertex Operator Algebras
div.p: We discuss some aspects of VOA theory to establish context and notation. For more details, see [FHL], [FLM], [Ka], [MN]. A vertex operator algebra (VOA) is a quadruple (V, Y, 1, ω) consisting of a Z-graded complex vector space V = n∈Z V n , a linear map Y : V → (EndV )[[z, z −1 ]] , and a pair of distinguished vectors (states): the vacuum 1 in V 0 , and the conformal vector ω in V 2 . We adopt mathematical rather than physical notation for vertex operators, so that for a state v in V , its image under the Y map is denoted

with component operators (or Fourier modes) v(n) ∈ EndV and where Y (v, z).1| z=0 = v(−1).1 = v. We generally take z to be a formal variable. A concession to physics notation is made concerning the vertex operator for the conformal vector ω, where we write Y (w, z) = n∈Z L(n)z −n−2 .
The modes L(n) close on the Virasoro Lie algebra of central charge c:
We define the homogeneous space of weight k to be V k = {v ∈ V |L(0)v = kv} where for v in V k we write wt(v) = k. Then as an operator on V we have v(n) : V m → V m+k−n−1 .

In particular, the zero mode o(v) = v(wt(v) − 1) is a linear operator on each homogeneous space of V . Next we consider some particular VOAs, namely Heisenberg VOAs (or free boson theories), and lattice VOAs. We consider an l-dimensional complex vector space (i.e., abelian Lie algebra) H equipped with a non-degenerate, symmetric, bilinear form (, ) and a distinguished orthonormal basis a 1 , a 2 , ...a l .
The corresponding affine Lie algebra is the Heisenberg Lie algebrâ H = H ⊗ C[t, t −1 ] ⊕ Ck with brackets [k, ˆ H] = 0 and [a ⊗ t m , b ⊗ t n ] = (a, b)mδ m,−n k. (18)

Corresponding to an element λ in the dual space H * we consider the Fock space defined by the induced (Verma) module M λ = U( ˆ H) ⊗ U (H⊗C[t]⊕Ck) C, where C is the 1-dimensional space annihilated by H ⊗ tC[t] and on which k acts as the identity and H ⊗ t 0 via the character λ; U denotes the universal enveloping algebra. There is a canonical identification of linear spaces M λ = S(H ⊗ t −1 C[t −1 ]), where S denotes the (graded) symmetric algebra. The Heisenberg VOA M corresponds to the case λ = 0 and the Fock states

for non-negative integers e i , ..., f j form a basis of M. The vacuum 1 is canonically identified with the identity of M 0 = C, while the weight 1 subspace M 1 may be naturally identified with H. The vertex operator corresponding to h in H is given by

where h(n) is the usual operator on M. M is a simple VOA. Next we consider the case of lattice VOAs V L associated to a positivedefinite , even lattice L ([B], [FLM]). Thus L is a free abelian group of rank l, say, equipped with a positive definite, integral bilinear form (, ) : L ⊗ L → Z such that (α, α) is even for α ∈ L. Let H be the space C ⊗ Z L equipped with the C-linear extension of (, ) to H ⊗ H and let M be the corresponding Heisenberg VOA. The Fock space of the lattice theory may be described by the linear space V L = M ⊗ C[L]

figure.trash: = α∈L M ⊗ e α , (21) where C[L]

div.p: denotes the group algebra of L with canonical basis e α , α ∈ L. M may be identified with the subspace M ⊗ e 0 of V L , in which case M is a subVOA of V L and the rightmost equation of (21) then displays the decomposition of V L into irreducible M-modules. We identify e α with the element 1 ⊗ e α in V L ; each of the elements e α is a primary state of weight (α, α)/2. The vertex operator for h in H is again represented in the obvious way by (20). The vertex operator for e α is more complicated (loc. cit.) and is given by

figure.trash: Y (e α , z) = Y − (e α , z)Y + (e α , z)e α z α , Y ± (e α , z) = exp(∓ n>0 α(±n) n z ∓n ). (22)

div.p: (The slight inconsistency in notation is more than compensated by its convenience ). The operators e α ∈ C[L]

figure.trash: have group commutator e α e β e −α e −β = (−1) (α,β) , (23) and e α , z α act on any state u ⊗ e β ∈ V L as e α (u ⊗ e β ) = ǫ(α, β)u ⊗ e α+β , (24) z α (u ⊗ e β ) = z (α,β) u ⊗ e β , (25)

div.p: for cocycle ǫ(α, β) = ±1. This cocycle can be chosen so that [FLM]

In the context of his theory of modular-invariance for n-point functions at genus 1, Zhu introduced in [Z] a second VOA (V, Y [, ], 1, ˜ ω) associated to a given VOA (V, Y (, ), 1, ω). This will be important in the present paper, and we review some aspects of the construction here. The underlying Fock space of the second VOA is the same space V as the first, moreover they share the same vacuum vector 1 and have the same central charge. The new vertex operators are defined by a change of co-ordinates 1 , namely Y [v, z] = n∈Z v[n]

figure.trash: z −n−1 = Y (q L(0) z v, q z − 1), (28) while the new conformal vector ω is defined to be the state ω − c 24 1. We set Y [˜ ω, z] = n∈Z L[n]z −n−2 (29) and write wt[v]

div.p: = k if L[0].v = kv, V [k] = {v ∈ V |wt[v] = k}. States homogeneous with respect to the first degree operator L(0) are not necessarily homogeneous with respect to L[0]. On the other hand, it transpires (cf. [Z], [DLM]) that the two Virasoro algebras enjoy the same set of primary states. We have L[−1] = L(0) + L(−1), which leads to the useful relation o(L[−1]v) = 0, (30) for any state v. Inasmuch as the co-ordinate change z → q z = exp(z) maps the complex plane to an infinite cylinder, we sometimes refer to the VOA as being 'on the sphere', or 'on the cylinder '. The Heisenberg VOA M is a simple example where there is not too much difference between being on the sphere or the cylinder. This is basically because M is generated by its weight 1 states which are primary for both Virasoro algebras, and because we have u[1]v = u(1)v = (u, v)1 and the commutator formula [u[m], v[n]] = m(u, v)δ m,−n , (31) for weight 1 states u, v ∈ M (cf. [Z], [DMN] for more details).

div.head: Torus n-point Functions
div.p: In this section we will consider n-point functions at genus one. A general reference is Zhu's paper [Z]. Let (V, Y, 1, ω) be a vertex operator algebra as discussed in section 2 with N a V -module. Recall (loc. cit.) that for states v 1 , . . . v n ∈ V , the n-point function on the torus determined by N is

where q i = q z i , 1 ≤ i ≤ n, for auxiliary variables z 1 , ..., z n . (32) incorporates some cosmetic changes compared to [Z]: we have adorned our n-point functions with an extra factor q −c/24 and omitted a factor of 2πi from the variables z i (cf. footnote to (

figure.trash: 28)). In case n = 1, (32) is the usual trace function which we will often denote by Z N (v 1 , τ ) = T r N o(v 1 )q L(0)−c/24 (33) where o(v 1

div.p: ) again denotes the zero mode, now for the vertex operator Y (v 1 , z) acting on N. Note that this trace is independent of z 1 . Taking all v i = 1 in (32) yields the genus one partition function for N:

figure.trash: Z N (τ ) = T r N q L(0)−c/24 = q −c/24 m≥0 dim N m q m . (34)

div.p: where N m is the subspace of N of homogeneous vectors of conformal weight m.
The following result, which we use later, holds:

figure.trash: Lemma 3.1. For states v 1 , v 2 , . . . , v n as above we have F N (v 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n , z n ; q) = Z N (Y [v 1 , z 1n ]

div.p: .Y [v 2 , z 2n ] . . . Y [v n−1 , z n−1n ].v n , τ ) (35) = Z N (Y [v 1 , z 1 ].Y [v 2 , z 2 ] . . . Y [v n , z n ].1, τ ) (36) where z ij = z i − z j . Proof: Recall notation from section 2 for vertex operator algebras on the cylinder. Lemma 3.1 is implicit in [Z], section 4, especially eqn. (4.4.21).
We will give a direct proof in the case n = 2 based on the associativity of vertex operators. The general case follows in similar fashion. Associativity tells us ([FHL]

figure.trash: , Proposition 3.3.2) that T r N Y (v 1 , z 1 )Y (v 2 , z 2 )q L(0) = T r N Y (Y (v 1 , z 12 )v 2 ), z 2 )q L(0) . (37)

div.p: We also have ([FHL]

figure.trash: , eqn.(2.6.4)) e xL(0) Y (v, y)e −xL(0) = Y (e xL(0) v, e x y). (38) By (37) and (38) it follows that the left-hand-side of (36) is equal to T r N Y (Y (q L(0) 1 v 1 , q 1 − q 2 )q L(0) 2 v 2 , q 2 )q L(0)−c/24 = T r N Y (q L(0) 2 Y (q L(0) z 12 v 1 , q z 12 − 1).v 2 , q 2 )q L(0)−c/24 = T r N Y (q L(0) 2 Y [v 1 , z 12 ].v 2 , q 2 )q L(0)−c/24 = Z N (Y [v 1 , z 12 ].v 2 , τ ), as required. Finally using [FHL], eqn.(2.3.17) we have in general that e xL(−1) Y (v, y)e −xL(−1) = Y (v, y + x). (39) Hence (36) follows from o(Y [v 1 , z 12 ]

div.p: Recall from the previous section the notation for states and modules for Heisenberg and lattice vertex operator algebras. We are going to develop explicit formulas for n-point functions in these cases. The final answer is quite elaborate, so we begin with the rank 1 case. The general case will proceed in exactly the same manner. We fix the following notation: L is a rank l = 1 even lattice with inner product (, ), M the corresponding Heisenberg vertex operator algebra based on the complex space H = C ⊗ Z L, a ∈ H satisfies (a, a) = 1, N = M ⊗ e β is a simple M-module with β ∈ L, h = (β, β)/2 the conformal weight of the highest weight vector of N. We will establish a closed formula for n-point expressions of the form

figure.trash: F N (v 1 ⊗ e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n ⊗ e αn , z n ; q), (40) where α 1 , . . . , α

div.p: n ∈ L and v 1 , . . . , v n are elements in the canonical Fock basis (19) of M on the cylinder. Thus, v 1 = a[−1] e 1 a[−2] e 2 . . . , etc. Note that the individual vertex operators Y (v i ⊗ e α i , z i ), 1 ≤ i ≤ n do not generally act on the module N, however their composite does as long as α 1 + . . . + α n = 0. We will always assume that this is the case. It transpires that (40) factors as

where Q N is independent of the α i , and our main task will be to elucidate the structure of the two factors Q N and F N . Our results generalize the calculations in [DMN], which dealt with the case n = 1, α 1 = 0. We turn to the precise description of Q N . Consider first a Fock state v ∈ M given by v = a[−1] e 1 . . . a[−p] ep .1 (42) where e 1 , . . . , e p are non-negative integers . The state v is determined by a multi-set or labelled set, which consists of e 1 + e 2 + . . . + e p elements, the first e 1 of which are labelled 1, the next e 2 labelled 2, etc. In this way, each of the states v i in (40) is associated with a labelled set Φ i , and we let Φ = Φ 1 ∪ . . . ∪ Φ n denote the disjoint union of the Φ i , itself a labelled set. For convenience we often specify an element of Φ by its label: the reader should bear in mind that this expedient can be misleading because there are generally several distinct elements with the same label.
An element ϕ ∈ Inv(Φ) (cf. (14)) considered as a permutation of Φ, may be represented as a product of cycles, each of length 1 or 2:

) tells us that Φ = {r 1 , s 1 , . . . , r b , s b , t 1 , . . . , t c }, while ϕ exchanges elements with labels r i and s i , and fixes elements with labels t 1 , . . . , t c . Notice that involutions may produce the same permutation of labels yet correspond to distinct permutations of Φ. We will always consider such involutions to be distinct, regardless of labels. Recall the definitions (9) to (12). Let Ξ be a subset of Φ with |Ξ| ≤ 2. If Ξ = {r, s} has size 2 with r ∈ Φ i , s ∈ Φ j , we define

figure.trash: γ(Ξ) = D(r, s, z ij , τ ), i = j C(r, s, τ ), i = j. (44)

div.p: Note that D(r, s, z, τ ) = D(s, r, −z, τ ), so that the order in which the arguments r, s appear is of no relevance. If Ξ = {r} ⊆ Φ k we define

figure.trash: γ(Ξ) = (a, δ r,1 β + C(r, 0, τ )α k + l>k D(r, 0, z kl , τ )α l ). (45) For ϕ ∈ Inv(Φ) set Γ(ϕ) = Ξ γ(Ξ) (46) where the product ranges over all orbits (cycles) of ϕ in its action on Φ. Finally, set Q N (v 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n , z n ; q) = ϕ∈Inv(Φ) Γ(ϕ) (47)

div.p: We can now formally state our first main result about n-point functions.

figure.head: Proposition 3.2.
figure.figDesc: Let v 1 , . . . , v n be states of the form (42) in the rank 1 free boson theory M and let Φ be the labelled set determined (as above) by these states. Then the following holds for lattice elements α 1 ,
figure.trash: . . . , α n satisfying α 1 + . . . + α n = 0: F N (v 1 ⊗ e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n ⊗ e αn , z n ; q) = Q N (v 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n , z n ; q)F N (1 ⊗ e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; 1 ⊗ e αn , z n ; q). (48)

div.p: Proof: The idea is to carefully examine a recursion formula for n-point functions due to Zhu ([Z], Proposition 4.3.3). Bearing in mind the differences in notation between the present paper and [Z], we quote the following: Lemma 3.3 (Zhu). Assume that u 1 , . . . , u n , b are states in a vertex operator algebra V , that N is a V -module, and that o(b) acts as a scalar on N.
u k , z k ; ...; u n , z n ; q).

We apply this result in the case that N and u i = v i ⊗ e α i are as discussed in (40) -(47), with b = a. The zero mode of a acts on N as multiplication by the scalar (a, β) and a[0].v i ⊗ e α i = (a, α i )v i ⊗ e α i . As a result of α 1 + . . . + α n = 0 it follows that the last summand in (49) vanishes, and (49) then reads F N (a[−1]

figure.trash: v 1 ⊗ e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n ⊗ e αn , z n ; q) = (a, β + n k=2 D(1, 0, z 1k )α k )F N (v 1 ⊗ e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n ⊗ e αn , z n ; q) + k≥1 C(2k − 1, 1)F N (ˆ v 1 ⊗ e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n ⊗ e αn , z n ; q) + m≥1 n k=2 D(m, 1, z k1 )F N (v 1 ⊗ e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ˆ v k ⊗ e α k , z k ; . . . ; v n ⊗ e αn , z n ; q). (50)

div.p: Here, we have used the (admittedly uninformative) notation v 1 in the second summand to indicate that a factor a[−2k +1] should be removed from the expression of v 1 as a product (42), and indeed that this should be implemented as often as a[−2k + 1] occurs in the expression. If a[−2k + 1] does not occur in the expression for v 1 then v 1 is defined to be zero. Similar notation v k occurs in the third summand, where it indicates removal of a factor a[−m]. Next we develop the analog of (50) in which a[−1] is replaced by a[−p] for any positive integer p. To this end we take b = L[−1] p−1 .a. We easily calculate that b[m] = (−1) p−1 m p−1 a[m − p + 1], in particular b[−1] = a[−p] and b[0] = 0 if p ≥ 2. Note also that o(b) = 0 if p ≥ 2, thanks to (30). With this choice of b and p, and after some calculation, (49) reduces to the next equation. In fact, we can combine the resulting equality (for p ≥ 2) with the case p = 1. What obtains is the basic recursive relation satisfied by our n-point functions, namely F N (a[−p]

figure.figDesc: v 1 ⊗ e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n ⊗ e αn , z n ; q)
figure.trash: = k>p/2 C(2k − p, p)F N (ˆ v 1 ⊗ e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n ⊗ e αn , z n ; q) + m>p−1 n k=2 D(m − p + 1, p, z k1 ). F N (v 1 ⊗ e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; ˆ v k ⊗ e α k , z k ; . . . ; v n ⊗ e αn , z n ; q) +(a, δ p,1 β + C(p, 0)α 1 + n k=2 D(p, 0, z 1k )α k ). F N (v 1 ⊗ e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n ⊗ e αn , z n ; q), (51)

div.p: where we have used a similar convention to the case p = 1 regarding symbols v 1 , ˆ v k .

Close scrutiny of relation (51) reveals how to complete the proof of Proposition 3.2, which at this point is a matter of interpreting the recursion formula . We choose an element with label p from the first labelled set Φ 1 determined by v 1 . The first sum on the r.h.s of (51) then corresponds to certain terms in the representation (42) of v 1 . Indeed, as long as 2k > p, a factor a[p − 2k] will give rise to a term C(2k − p, p, τ )F N (...), and via (44) we identify C(2k − p, p, τ ) with γ(Ξ) where Ξ = {2k − p, p} ⊆ Φ 1 and (2k − p, p) is the initial transposition of a putative involution that is to be constructed inductively. Terms in the second (double) summation in (51) are treated similarly -they correspond to expressions γ(

figure.figDesc: Ξ)F N (...) where Ξ = {m − p + 1, p} and m − p + 1, p are labels of elements in Φ k , Φ 1 respectively (for k = 1). The third term in (51) is similarly seen to coincide with γ(Ξ)F N (...), now with Ξ = {p} ⊆ Φ 1 . We repeat this process in an inductive manner. It is easy to see that in this way we construct every element of Inv(Φ) exactly once, and what emerges is the formula (48). This completes our discussion of the proof of Proposition 3.2. In order to complete our discussion of the rank one n-point functions we must of course evaluate the term F N (1 ⊗ e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; 1 ⊗ e αn , z n ; q). Before we do that, however, it will be useful to draw some initial conclusions from Proposition 3.2. Taking all lattice elements α 1 = . . . = α n = β = 0 corresponds to the case of n-point functions in the rank 1 free bosonic theory M. In this case all contributions from orbits of length 1 vanish and hence the sum over Inv(Φ) reduces to one over F (Φ) of (16) only. Furthermore we know that F M (1, z 1 ; . . . ; 1, z n ; q) is just the partition function for M i.e. 1/η(τ ). Thus we arrive at a formula for n-point functions for a single free boson:
figure.head: Corollary 3.4.

figure.figDesc: Let M be the VOA for a single free boson. For Fock states v 1 , . . . , v n as in (42) with corresponding labelled set Φ we have F M (v 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n , z n ; q) =

div.p: The case n = 1 of Corollary 3.4 was established in [DMN], where it was shown that

figure.trash: Z M (v; τ ) = 1 η(τ ) ϕ∈F (Φ) C(r, s, τ ), (53)
figure.figDesc: for fixed point free involutions ϕ = . . . (rs) . . . of the labelled set Φ labelling v of (42) where the product is taken over all the transpositions (rs) in ϕ.

div.p: An even more special, yet interesting, case arises if in Corollary 3.4 we take each state v i to coincide with the conformal weight one state a. Thus v i = a[−1].1, 1 ≤ i ≤ n, Φ consists of n elements each carrying the label 1, and elements of Σ(Φ) may be considered as mappings on the set {1, 2, . . . , n} in the usual way. If n is odd then there are no fixed-point-free involutions acting on Φ, so (52) is zero in this case. If n is even then γ(Ξ) = P 2 (z ij , τ ) if Ξ = Φ i ∪ Φ j for i = j. Thus we obtain

figure.head: Corollary 3.5.
figure.figDesc: Let M be the VOA for a single free boson. Then for n even,
figure.trash: F M (a, z 1 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q) = 1 η(τ ) ϕ∈F (Φ) P 2 (z ij , τ ), (54)

figure.figDesc: where the product ranges over the cycles of ϕ = . . . (ij) . . .

div.p: We next consider the case of an M-module N = M ⊗ e β . If n = 1 we necessarily have α 1 = 0, Z N = q (β,β)/2 /η(τ ), and the labelled set Φ coincides with Φ 1 . If ϕ ∈ Inv(Φ) and Ξ = {r} is an orbit of ϕ of length 1 then from (45) we get γ(Ξ) = δ r,1 (a, β). So Γ(ϕ) vanishes unless all labels of the set of fixed-points Fix(ϕ) are equal to 1. In this case we may write ϕ = 1 |∆| ϕ 0 to indicate that ϕ fixes a set ∆ of elements with label 1, and that ϕ 0 is the fixed-point-free involution induced by ϕ on the complement Φ\∆. We thus obtain

figure.head: Corollary 3.6.
figure.figDesc: Let M be as in (40) and let N be the M-module M ⊗ e β . Take v to be the state (42) and let Λ denote the elements in Φ with label 1.

where ϕ 0 = . . . (rs) . . . acting on Φ\∆. Similarly to Corollary 3.5 we can consider again the special case with each v i = a, generalising (54). In the above notation we therefore have Λ = Φ so that
figure.head: Corollary 3.7.

figure.figDesc: Let M be the VOA for a single free boson with module N = M ⊗ e β . Then F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q) = q
where the product ranges over the cycles of ϕ 0 = . . . (ij) . . .

div.p: We now show how (56) can be interpreted as the generator of all free bosonic n-point functions for Fock states (19). This provides a useful insight into the structure found for these n-point functions in terms of the elliptic function P 2 (z, τ ) and the scalar (a, β).

figure.head: Proposition 3.8
figure.figDesc: . F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q) is a generating function for the npoint functions for all Fock states v 1 , . . . , v n .

figure.head: Proof.
figure.figDesc: This follows from Lemma 3.1 and the expansions of P 2 of (7) and (8). We will illustrate the result for n = 1 and n = 2. A general proof can be given along the same lines. From (36) we obtain F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q) = Z N (Y [a, z 1 ]

figure.trash: = l 1 ,...ln∈Z Z N (a[−l 1 ]

div.p: The 1-point function for the bosonic Fock state v = a[−l 1 ] . . . a[−l n ].1 is clearly the coefficient of z

p.formula: l 1 −1 1 . . . z ln−1 n for l 1 , .

div.p: . . , l n > 0. We then recover (55) from the expansion for each P 2 (z ij , τ ) using (7). For n = 2 consider the 1-point function Z N (Y [Y [a, w 1 ] . . . Y [a, w m ].1, w].Y [Y [a, z 1 ] . . . Y [a, z n ].1, z].1, q). (58)
The 2-point function F N (v 1 , q 1 ; v 2 , q 2 ; q) for v 1 = a[−l 1 ] . . . a[−l m ].1 and v 2 = a[−k 1 ] . . . a[−k n ].1 is the coefficient of

p.formula: m i=1 n j=1 w l i −1 i z

div.p: m j −1 j in (58). By associativity (37) and using Y [1, z] = Id eqn. (58) can be expressed as Z N (Y [a, w 1 + w] . . . Y [a, w m + w].Y [a, z 1 + z] . . . Y [a, z n + z].1, q).
Using (56) this becomes (suppressing the τ dependence for clarity)

div.head: q

figure.figDesc: P 2 (w ab ) . . . P 2 (z cd ) . . . P 2 (w − z + w e − z f ) . . . where ϕ 0 = (ab) . . . (cd) . . . (ef ) . . . ∈ F (Φ\∆) with a, b, e . . . ∈ {1, 2, . . . m} and c, d, f . . . ∈ {1, 2, . . . n}. Then the coefficient of w
figure.trash: la−1 a w l b −1 b in P 2 (w ab ) is C(l a , l b ), the coefficient of z mc−1 c z m d −1 d in P 2 (z cd ) is C(m c , m d ) from (7) and the coefficient of w le−1 e z m f −1 f in P 2

div.p: (w − z + w e − z f ) is D(l e , m f , w − z) from (8) leading to the result (52) in this case.

We complete our discussion of bosonic n-point functions with two global formulas for 1-point functions. The first shows how to write certain 1-point functions with respect to N in terms of 1-point functions with respect to M:

figure.head: Proposition 3.9.
figure.figDesc: Let notation be as in Corollary 3.4. Then if ς is an in- determinate,
figure.trash: Z N (exp( m≥1 1 m a[−m]ς m ).1, τ ) = q (β,β)/2 exp((a, β)ς)Z M (exp( m≥1 1 m a[−m]ς m ).1, τ ). (59)

figure.head: Proposition 3.10.
figure.figDesc: Let λ 1 , . . . λ n be n scalars obeying n i=1 λ i = 0. Then the following holds:

div.p: Z M (exp( m≥1 a[−m]

figure.trash: m n i=1 λ i z m i ).1, τ ) = 1 η(τ ) 1≤i<j≤n ( K(z ij , τ ) z ij ) λ i λ j , (60) where K(z, τ

div.p: ) is the prime form of (5).
We divide the proof of Proposition 3.9 into several steps.

figure.head: Lemma 3.11.
figure.figDesc: Let u ∈ M be a state such that a[1]

div.p: .u = 0. For an integer p ≥ 0, Z N (a[−1] p .u, q) = q (β,β)/2 Z M ((a, β) + a[−1]) p .u, q).

Proof: Suppose first that p = 0. In this case, the lemma says that for a state v as in (42) which satisfies also e 1 = 0, the traces of o(v) over N and M differ only by an overall factor of q (β,β)/2 . A moment's thought shows that this follows from Corollary 3.4 because the set Λ is empty in this case. This proves the case p = 0 of the lemma.
We prove the general case by induction on p. Using lemma 3.3 with n = 1 we calculate Z N (a[−1]
.(a, β) + a[−1]) p .u, τ ), from which the result follows by using lemma 3.3 again. If we multiply (61) by ς p , rearrange the constants and sum over p we find

div.head: Lemma 3.12. Let notation be as above. Then
div.p: Z N (exp(a[−1]ς).u, τ ) = q (β,β)/2 exp((a, β)ς)Z M (exp a[−1]ς).u, τ ). (62)

Choosing u = exp( m≥2 a[−m] m ς m ).1 we note that Proposition 3.9 is a special case of lemma 3.12. Proof of Proposition 3.10: When expanded as a sum, the left-handside of (60) can be written in the form

figure.trash: v p k=1 1 e k ! ( 1 k n i=1 λ i z k i ) e k Z M (v, τ ), (63)

div.p: where v ranges over the basis elements (42). In this regard one should note that as a consequence of Corollary 3.4, Z M (v, τ ) = 0 whenever p k=1 ke k is odd. The argument that we use to establish the equality (60) involves the use of a combinatorial technique that proliferates in other work on genus two and higher VOAs [MT].

figure.trash: Use the case N = M of (55) and use Corollary 3.4 to write (63) as 1 η(τ ) v p k=1 1 e k ! ϕ∈F (Φv) p k=1 Γ(ϕ)( 1 k n i=1 λ i z k i ) e k (64)

div.p: where Φ v is the labelled set determined by v. Fix for a moment an element ϕ, considered as a product of transpositions. We can represent ϕ by a graph with nodes labelled by positive integers corresponding to the elements of Φ v , two nodes being connected precisely when ϕ interchanges the nodes in question. Such a graph masquerades under various names in combinatorics: bipartite graph, or a complete matching (cf. [LW], for example), and is nothing more than another way to think about fixed-point-free involutions.

figure.figDesc: Pictorially the complete matching looks like r 1 • —– • s 1 r 2 • —– • s 2 . . . r b • —– • s b Fig.1

div.p: We denote the complete matching determined by ϕ by the symbol µ ϕ .

Any complete matching on a set labelled by positive integers corresponds to a fixed-point-free involution and a state v. Let us agree that two complete matchings µ 1 , µ 2 are isomorphic if there is a bijection from the node set of µ 1 to the node set of µ 2 that preserves labels. We may identify the node sets of the two matchings, call it Φ, in which case an isomorphism may be realized by an element in the symmetric group Σ(Φ). More precisely, let us define the label subgroup of Σ(Φ) to be the subgroup Λ(Φ) consisting of all permutations of Φ that preserve labels. Then it is the case that an isomorphism between µ 1 and µ 2 may be realized by an element in the label subgroup. Note that our notation implies that |Λ(Φ)| = e k !. Now consider (64). The expression to the right of the second summation, which we denote by

figure.trash: ˆ Γ(µ ϕ ) = p k=1 Γ(ϕ)( 1 k n i=1 λ i z k i ) e k (65)

div.p: is determined by the complete matching µ ϕ . By what we have said, every complete matching on a set labelled by positive integers occurs in this way as v ranges over the preferred Fock basis of M (on the cylinder) and ϕ ranges over F (Φ v ), while the factor 1 e k ! may be interpreted as averaging over all complete matchings with a given set of labels. The only duplication that occurs is due to automorphisms of the complete matching. The upshot is that expression (64) is equal to

figure.trash: 1 η(τ ) µ ˆ Γ(µ) |Aut(µ)| (66)

div.p: where µ ranges over all isomorphism classes of complete matchings labelled by positive integers. For a given complete matching µ as in Fig. 1, let E = E(r, s) denote an edge with labels r, s, and let m(E) denote the multiplicity of E in µ. Thus we may represent µ symbolically by its decomposition µ = m(E)E into isomorphism classes of labelled edges. Now it is evident that there is an isomorphism of groups
Aut(µ) ≃ E Aut(E) ≀ Σ m(E) , a direct product, indexed by isomorphism classes of labelled edges, of groups which are themselves the (regular) wreathed product of Aut(E) and Σ m(E) .
In particular, we have

figure.trash: |Aut(µ)| = E m(E)!|Aut(E)| m(E) . (67)

div.p: Note that |Aut(E)| ≤ 2, with equality only if the two node labels of E are equal. Next it is easy to see that the expression Γ(µ) is multiplicative over edges.

figure.trash: In other words, we have ˆ Γ(µ) = E ˆ Γ(E) m(E) , (68) and for an edge E(r, s) we have ˆ Γ(E) = C(r, s, τ )( 1 r n i=1 λ i z r i )( 1 s n j=1 λ j z s j ) = (−1) r+1 r + s r + s s E r+s (τ ) n i=1 λ i z r i n j=1 λ j z s j . (69) Substitute (67) and (68) in (66) to obtain the expression 1 η(τ ) E exp( ˆ Γ(E) |Aut(E)| ) = 1 η(τ ) exp( Eor Γ(E or ) 2 ), (70)

div.p: where E ranges over all labelled edges r@BULLET——@BULLETs and E or ranges over all oriented edges r@BULLET—¿—@BULLETs (which have trivial automorphism group).

figure.trash: Using (69), the expression (70) is in turn equal to 1 η(τ ) exp( 1 2 k≥1 E 2k (τ ) 1 2k 2k r=0 (−1) r+1 2k r n i=1 λ i z r i n j=1 λ j z 2k−r j ). (71) But, 1 2 2k r=0 (−1) r+1 2k r n i=1 λ i z r i n j=1 λ j z 2k−r j = − 1≤i<j≤n λ i λ j z 2k ij . and hence using (4), (5) we find (71) becomes 1 η(τ ) 1≤i<j≤n exp(−λ i λ j (P 0 (z ij , τ ) + log z ij )) = 1 η(τ ) 1≤i<j≤n [ K(z ij , τ ) z ij ]

div.p: λ i λ j .
This completes the proof of Proposition 3.10. We now turn our attention on the second factor F N of (41) where we abbreviate 1 ⊗ e α i by e α i again.

figure.head: Proposition 3.13.
figure.figDesc: Let M and N be as above, and let α 1 , . . . , α n be lattice elements in the rank one even lattice L satisfying α 1 + . . . + α n = 0. Then
figure.trash: F N (e α 1 , z 1 ; ...; e αn , z n ; q) = q (β,β)/2 η(τ ) 1≤r≤n exp((β, α r )z r ) 1≤i<j≤n ǫ(α i , α j )K(z ij , τ ) (α i ,α j ) . (72)

figure.figDesc: Proof: Use (36) of Lemma 3.1 to rewrite the LHS of (72) as Z N (o(Y [e α 1 , z 1 ]

div.p: Referring to (22), by repeated use of the identity

figure.trash: Y + (e α , z)Y − (e β , w) = ( z − w z ) (α,β) Y − (e β , w)Y + (e α , z) (for |z| > |w| ) and using (24) to (26) we find (73) is 1≤r<s≤n z rs (αr,αs) ǫ(α r , α s )Z N (exp( m>0 n i=1 α i [−m] m z m i ).1,τ ). (74)

div.p: The operator corresponding to m = 1 in the exponential in (74) may be written in the form a[−1]ς where ς = n k=1 (a, α k )z k so that, from Lemma 3.12, Z N (exp( m>0 n i=1 α i [−m]

figure.trash: m z m i ).1,τ ) = q (β,β)/2 n i=1 exp((β, α i )z i )Z M (exp( m>0 n i=1 α i [−m]

div.p: m z m i ).1,τ )
Now use Proposition 3.10 with λ i = (a, α i ) so that we find Z M (exp( m>0 n i=1 α i [−m]

figure.trash: m z m i ).1,τ ) = 1 η(τ ) 1≤i<j≤n [ K(z ij , τ ) z ij ]

div.p: (α i ,α j ) .

This completes the proof of the Proposition. We now consider the lattice VOA V L constructed from a rank l even lattice L as described in section 2. We recall that a 1 , a 2 , ...a l is an orthonormal basis for H with respect to the non-degenerate symmetric bilinear form (, ). We let M be the rank l Heisenberg vertex operator algebra and let N = M ⊗ e β be a simple M-module with β ∈ L, h = (β, β)/2 the conformal weight of the highest weight vector of N. Then M ≃ M 1 ⊗ . . . ⊗ M l , the tensor product of l copies of the rank 1 Heisenberg VOA, and is spanned by the Fock states v = a 1 [−1] e 1 . . . a 1 [−p] ep . . . a l [−1] f 1 . . . a l [−q] fq .1 (75) where e 1 , . . . , f q are non-negative integers. We now give a general closed formula for all rank l lattice n-point functions (40) where v 1 , . . . , v n are Fock states of the form (75). Viewing each vector v i as an element of M 1 ⊗ . . . ⊗ M l we define Φ r i as the labelled set for the r th tensored vector of v i e.g. Φ 1 i contains 1 with multiplicity e 1 , 2 with multiplicity e 2 etc. Therefore, v i is determined by the labelled set Φ i = Φ 1 i ∪ . . . ∪ Φ l i , the disjoint union of l sets. We also define Φ r = 1≤i≤n Φ r i to be the labelled set for the r th tensored vectors of the n vectors v 1 , . . . , v n .
Then we have:

figure.head: Theorem 3.14.
figure.figDesc: Let v 1 , . . . , v n be states of the form (75) in the rank l free boson theory M and let Φ 1 , . . . Φ l be the labelled sets defined as above by these states. Then the following holds for lattice elements α 1 , . . . , α n ∈ L satisfying α 1 + . . . + α n = 0: F N (v 1 ⊗ e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n ⊗ e αn , z n ; q) = Q N (v 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n , z n ; q)F N (e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; e αn , z n ; q),
figure.trash: (76) where Q N (v 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n , z n ; q) = 1≤r≤l ϕ r ∈Inv(Φ r ) Γ(ϕ r ), (77) and F N (e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; e αn , z n ; q) = q (β,β)/2 η(τ ) l 1≤r≤n exp((β, α r )z r ) 1≤i<j≤n

div.p: ǫ(α i , α j )K(z ij , τ ) (α i ,α j ) . (78)

div.head: Proof.
div.p: We sketch the proof which follows along the same lines as the rank one case described above. We firstly apply Lemma 3.3 to the r th tensored vectors labelled by Φ r . Following the same argument for the rank one case in Proposition 3.2, this results in (76) and (77). We secondly evaluate the LHS of (78) as in Proposition 3.13 using Proposition 3.10 with λ r i = (a r , α i ) for r = 1, . . . , l to obtain (78).
We conclude this section with the first non-trivial examples of lattice npoint functions which occur for n = 2. From Theorem 3.14 and recalling (27) we have:

figure.head: Corollary 3.15.
figure.figDesc: For a rank l lattice theory with N as above and with states e α and e −α we have:
figure.trash: F N (e α , z 1 ; e −α , z 2 ; q) = q (β,β)/2 η l (τ ) exp((β, α)z 12 ) K(z 12 , τ ) (α,α) . (79)

div.p: Taking the sum over all β ∈ L we immediately obtain:

figure.head: Corollary 3.16.
figure.figDesc: For V = V L , the lattice vertex operator algebra for a rank l even lattice L, and for states e α and e −α we have:
figure.trash: F V L (e α , z 1 ; e −α , z 2 ; q) = 1 η l (τ ) Θ α,L (τ, z 12 /2πi) K(z 12 , τ ) (α,α) , (80) where Θ α,L (τ, z) = β∈L exp(2πi[ (β, β) 2 τ + (β, α)z]), (81)

div.head: is a Jacobi form of weight
div.p: l and index (α, α)/2 [EZ]

div.head: The Elliptic Properties of n-point Functions
div.p: In this section we will consider the elliptic properties of the n-point functions described in the previous section. For vertex operator algebras satisfying the so-called C 2 condition, Zhu has shown that every n-point function is meromorphic and periodic in each parameter z i and is therefore elliptic [Z]. The C 2 condition does not hold for simple modules of free bosonic theories but nevertheless all n-point functions (76) are found to be meromorphic and either elliptic for the free bosonic n-point functions or quasi-elliptic for the lattice n-point functions. In this section we will consider these n-point functions from first principles where our aim is to provide further insight into the structure found for these functions. In particular, we will show how (56), the generating function for free bosonic n-point functions and the lattice n-point function (72) are the unique elliptic or quasi-elliptic functions determined by permutation symmetry, periodicity and certain natural singularity and normalisation properties. We begin with a general statement about n-point functions:

figure.head: Lemma 4.1.
figure.figDesc: The n-point function F N = F N (v 1 ⊗ e α 1 , z 1 ; . . . ; v n ⊗ e αn , z n ; q) for α 1 + . . . + α n = 0 obeys the following: (i) F N is symmetric under all permutations of its indices.

div.p: (ii) F N is a function of z ij = z i − z j .
(iii) F N is non-singular at z ij = 0 for all i = j. (iv) F N is periodic in z i with period 2πi. (v) F N is quasi-periodic in z i with period 2πiτ and multiplier q (α i ,α i )/2+(α i ,β) q

Proof. (i) Apply the general locality property for vertex operators e.g. [Ka] (z − w) N Y (u, z).Y (v, w) = (z − w) N Y (v, w).Y (u, z), for N sufficiently large, to all adjacent pairs of operators in (36) of Lemma 3.1. (ii) This follows from (i) and (35) of Lemma 3.1. (iii) Suppose that F N is singular at z n = z 0 for some z 0 = z j for all j = 1, . . . , n − 1. Using (ii) we may assume that z 0 = 0 by redefining z i to be z i − z 0 for all i. But F N cannot be singular at z n = 0 from (36) of Lemma 3.1 since Y [v n ⊗ e αn , z n ].1| zn=0 = v n and hence the result follows. (iv) This follows from the integrality of conformal weights.

figure.trash: (v) Using (i) we have F N = q −c/24 T r N Y (q L(0) 2 v 2 ⊗ e α 2 , q 2 ). . . . Y (q L(0) n v n ⊗ e αn , q n ).Y (q L(0) 1 v 1 ⊗ e α 1 , q 1 )q L(0) . Under z 1 → z 1 + 2πiτ we have F N → ˆ F N where ˆ F N = q −c/24 T r N Y (q L(0) 2 v 2 ⊗ e α 2 , q 2 ). . . . Y (q L(0) n v n ⊗ e αn , q n ).q L(0) .Y (q L(0) 1 v 1 ⊗ e α 1 , q 1 ), (83) using (38). Consider the co-cycle parts of the vertex operators within F N . Using (23) to (25) we see that 2≤r≤n e αr .q αr r .q L(0) .e α 1 .q α 1 1 .(v ⊗ e β ) = q (α 1 ,α 1 )/2+(α 1 ,β) q (α 1 ,α 1 ) 1 1≤r≤n e αr .q αr r .q L(0) .(v ⊗ e β ). (84)

div.p: Since N = n∈Z M n ⊗ e β , the graded trace (83) decomposes into finite dimensional traces over M n to which we may apply the standard trace property T rAB = T rBA on the remaining parts of the vertex operators within

figure.trash: F N . Hence we obtain ˆ F N = q (α 1 ,α 1 )/2+(α 1 ,β) q (α 1 ,α 1 ) 1
figure.figDesc: F N ,

div.p: as required. By (i) we obtain the quasi-periodicity (82) for each z i .

Let us now consider the generating function, F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q), for all Fock state n-point functions for the rank one case. Note that F N (q) ≡ Z N (q) = q (β,β)/2 /η(τ ) for n = 0. From Lemma 4.1, F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q) is periodic in each z i with periods 2πi and 2πiτ . The singularity structure at z ij = 0 is determined by

figure.head: Lemma 4.2.
figure.figDesc: For n ≥ 2 and for i = j, F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q) has the following leading behaviour in its (formal) Laurent expansion in z ij
figure.trash: F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q) = 1 z 2 ij F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; ˆ a, ˆ z i . . . ; ˆ a, ˆ z j . . . ; a, z n ; q) + . . . , (85) wherê a, ˆ z i and a, ˆ z j denotes the deletion of the corresponding vertex operators resulting in an n − 2 point function. Y [a, z n−1n ].a = 1 z 2 n−1n 1 + k≥1 z k−1 n−1n a[−k]

div.p: We also have the following integral normalisation:

figure.trash: Lemma 4.3. For each i = 1, . . . , n ≥ 1 1 2πi 2πi 0
figure.figDesc: F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q)dz i = (a, β)F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; ˆ a, ˆ z i ; . . . ; a, z n ; q),
wherê a, ˆ z i denotes the deletion of the corresponding vertex operator giving an n − 1 point function.
figure.trash: Proof. Using Lemma 4.1 (i) it suffices to consider i = 1 only. Then the integral is 1 2πi 2πi 0 F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q)dz 1 = T r N 1 2πi C 1 Y (a, q 1 )dq 1 Y (q 2 a, q 2 ) . . . Y (q n v n , q n )q L(0)−1/24 = T r N o(a)Y (q 2 a, q 2 ) . . . Y (q n v n , q n )q L(0)−1/24 = (a, β)T r N Y (q 2 a, q 2 ) . . . Y (q n v n , q n )q L(0)−1/24 .

div.p: where C 1 denotes a closed contour surrounding q 1 = 0. We now show that F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q) is uniquely determined to be given by (56) of

figure.head: Corollary 3.7 as follows:
figure.figDesc: Proposition 4.4. F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q) is the unique meromorphic function in z i ∈ C/{2πi(m + nτ )|m, n ∈ Z} obeying Lemmas 4.1, 4.2 and 4.3 and is given by (56).

div.p: Proof. If F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q) is meromorphic then it is an elliptic function from Lemma 4.1 (iv) and (v). We prove the required result by induction. For n = 1, F N (a, z 1 ; q) has no poles from Lemma 4.1 (iii) and is therefore constant in z 1 .

figure.trash: Then (86) of Lemma 4.3 implies F N (a, z 1 ; q) = (a, β) q (β,β)/2 η(τ ) , in agreement with the RHS of (56) in this case. Next consider the elliptic function G(z 1 , . . . , z n ) = F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q) − n i=2 P 2 (z 1i )F N (a, z 2 ; . . . ; ˆ a, ˆ z i ; . . . ; a, z n ; q), wherê a, ˆ z

div.p: i denotes the deletion of the corresponding vertex operator. From Lemma 4.2, G is holomorphic and elliptic in z 1 and is therefore independent of z 1 . Next note that although not an elliptic function, P 1 (z, τ ) is periodic with period 2πi and so

figure.trash: 2πi 0 P 2 (z 1i , τ )dz 1 = 0. Hence Lemma 4.3 implies F N (a, z 1 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q) = (a, β)F N (a, z 2 ; . . . ; a, z n ; q) + n i=2 P 2 (z 1i )F N (a, z 2 ; . . . ; ˆ a, ˆ z i ; . . . ; a, z n ; q). (87)

div.p: But this recurrence relation is precisely (50) with v 1 = 1, v 2 = . . . = v n = a and α i = 0. Thus we obtain the RHS of (56) by induction as before.

figure.head: Remark 4.5.
figure.figDesc: The rank l result follows as before by considering the tensor product of l rank one Heisenberg VOAs.

div.p: We now consider the lattice n-point function F N (e α 1 , z 1 ; ...; e αn , z n ; q) for a rank l lattice. We firstly note the following:

figure.head: Lemma 4.6.
figure.figDesc: For n ≥ 1 and for i = j, the (formal) Laurent expansion in z ij of F N (e α 1 , z 1 ; ...; e αn , z n ; q) has leading behaviour
figure.trash: F N (e α 1 , z 1 ; ...; e αn , z n ; q) = ǫ(α i , α j )z (α i ,α j ) ij F N (e α 1 , z 1 ; ...ˆ e α i , ˆ z i ; . . . e α i +α j , z j ; . . . ; e αn , z n ; q) + . . . , (88) wherê e α i , ˆ z i

figure.figDesc: denotes the deletion of the corresponding vertex operator resulting in an n − 1 point function.

div.head: Y [e α n−1 , z n−1n ]
div.p: .e αn = ǫ(α n−1 , α n )z (α n−1 ,αn) n−1n e αn+α n−1 + . . .
Next recall the following properties for the prime form K(z, τ ) e.g. [Mu] Lemma 4.7. The genus one prime form K(z, τ ) is a holomorphic function on C/{2πi(m + nτ )|m, n ∈ Z} given by

figure.trash: K(z, τ ) = − iθ 1 (z, τ ) η(τ ) 3 , (89) θ 1 (z, τ ) ≡ n∈Z exp(πiτ (n + 1/2) 2 + (n + 1/2)(z + iπ)), (90) where K(z, τ

div.p: ) is quasi-periodic in z with period 2πi and multiplier −1 and with period 2πiτ and multiplier −q −1/2 q −1 z . Furthermore K(z, τ ) has a unique zero at z = 0 on C/{2πi(m + nτ )|m, n ∈ Z}.
We finally show that F N (e α 1 , z 1 ; ...; e αn , z n ; q) is uniquely determined to be given by (78) as follows:

figure.head: Proposition 4
figure.figDesc: .8. F N (e α 1 , z 1 ; ...; e αn , z n ; q) is the unique meromorphic function in z i ∈ C/{2πi(m + nτ )|m, n ∈ Z} obeying Lemmas 4.1 and 4.6.
figure.trash: Proof. If F N (e α 1 , z 1 ; ...; e αn , z n ; q) is meromorphic then consider the meromorphic function G(z 1 , . . . , z n ) = F N (e α 1 , z 1 ; ...; e αn , z n ; q) 1≤r≤n exp((β, α r )z r ) 1≤i<j≤n ǫ(α i , α j )K(z ij , τ ) (α i ,α j ) . (91)

div.p: We wish to show that G = F N (q) = η(τ ) l . We prove this by induction in n. It is easy to see that G is periodic with periods 2πi, 2πiτ using Lemma 4.1 (iv),(v) and Lemma 4.7 and hence G is elliptic in z i . G is also a function of z ij and considering the Laurent expansion in z ij one finds that the leading term is given by

div.head: G
div.p: using Lemma 4.6 and (26) and induction. Hence G is regular at z ij = 0. But the denominator of G has zeros possible only at z ij = 0 (for (α i , α j ) > 0) and hence G is a holomorphic elliptic function and is therefore constant in z i . Thus G(z 1 , . . . , z n ) = F N (q) and the result follows.

body.note: * Partial support provided by NSF DMS -9709820 and the Committee on Research, University of California, Santa Cruz † Supported by an Enterprise Ireland Basic Research Grant and the Millenium Fund, National University of Ireland, Galway

Concerning the co-ordinate change we follow [DLM] rather than [Z]. The latter has z replaced by 2πiz in (28). This leads to minor discrepancies between the notation in [Z] and the present paper which should be borne in mind.
